text: On top of a soft, cushiony baguette and a slab of creamy butter, a thin slice of briny, toothsome bottarga grows more mellow. Follow that bite with a sip of Lola’s unctuous, peachy Riesling and you’ll wonder where the pairing has been all your life. https://t.co/mMPQcRjhO6

name: sfchronicle
text: Today's front page: the stories San Francisco is talking about this morning. https://t.co/sgK7iFvtYo https://t.co/JOOQk1cEgp

name: sfchronicle
text:
RT @TimothyORourke: 🚨 Must-read project alert 🚨

Theo is 7, and he’s been homeless most of his life.

@sfchronicle photographer @gabriellelurie and reporter @SarRavani followed Theo and his mother for a year to try to capture the intractability of the homelessness crisis.

https://t.co/H9J6kGEqtb

name: sfchronicle
text:
We tend to mark moments with objects. We can also mark them with actions. 

Reporter @RyanKost asked Oakland artist @IndiraAllegra how to honor our grief in this moment in time. https://t.co/uIrT2Cirxr https://t.co/8NxWL9Tqsv

name: sfchronicle
text: The Homekey program, created in the recently passed state budget, will give California cities and counties $600 million to build on another state initiative that has moved thousands of homeless people into hotel rooms during the coronavirus pandemic. https://t.co/fp53CjUGHS

name: sfchronicle
text: Although cabins, visitor centers and historical sites are shut down, all parking lots, trailheads and campgrounds are open at Mount Tamalpais State Park, making it a top Bay Area staycation option for outdoor travel, writes @StienstraTom. https://t.co/lyvKg3CAT4 https://t.co/9OZqZjJpFA

name: sfchronicle
text: Bay Area officials are racing to put together proposals to buy hotels and motels as the state prepares to hand out hundreds of millions of dollars for properties that can be turned into permanent housing for homeless people. https://t.co/qE0BtdfUH1

name: sfchronicle
text: More than 300 tents were taken down in the Tenderloin, and 500 homeless people moved into hotel rooms leased by the city. https://t.co/laSd2PuerS

name: sfchronicle
text:
RT @SarRavani: All he wants is his own room and a kitchen where he can bake chocolate cake. He dreams of it while he sleeps in tents in parks and under the freeway.

He's 7.

This is the story of Theo. https://t.co/chDUBFT0II

name: sfchronicle

name: sfchronicle
text: Berkeley’s official homeless count showed no children among the more than 813 unsheltered people in the city in 201… https://t.co/F560vm39HB

name: sfchronicle
text: For Theo and his mother, life follows a seemingly perpetual cycle: They find a park to camp in, concerned residents… https://t.co/zOsG1ZH8GU

name: sfchronicle
text: Then they are back on the street, living in a tent in a new park, where a new set of neighbors outraged at the sigh… https://t.co/wBTWn1uMus

name: sfchronicle
text: The Chronicle followed Theo and his mother over the course of a year to try to capture, through the experience of a child living on the margins of an affluent community like Berkeley, the intractability of California’s homelessness crisis. https://t.co/qurLRipoEB

name: sfchronicle
text:
Black Panther Frances Moore has been feeding her North Oakland neighbors for 11 years through the Self-Help Hunger Program.

Amid the pandemic, she's transformed the program to keep homeless and other vulnerable people safe.

🎥: @CaronCreighton
Read more: https://t.co/f0YtQ5BmO3 https://t.co/fDxntfk4DZ

text: For every big wine cashing in on the “clean wine” craze, there are a dozen small-scale, thoughtful winemakers quietly making natural wines here in California. Wine critic @Esther_Mobley gets you started here: https://t.co/8Ro8TZOyVg

text: There were 383 active coronavirus cases at San Quentin State Prison as of Wednesday, according to the CDCR. Positive cases have been dropping after the massive outbreak peaked in early July. In total, 2,168 inmates have been infected and 19 have died. https://t.co/2SpmJ4B1VT

name: sfchronicle
text:
The husband-wife team behind San Francisco’s upcoming Marlena Restaurant is striving to find a balance between approachable and, potentially, Michelin-starred dining.

“We want to be a place you can come to on a Tuesday and also celebrate your birthday.”

https://t.co/dzmywZJdwD

name: sfchronicle
text: The SFPUC is offering city residents a small break on their energy bills in October. The agency will offer $50 credits for single-family homes, $750 credits for nonprofits and up to $3,000 for multi-family buildings. https://t.co/xIlX9fYn5S

name: sfchronicle
text: A San Francisco judge has refused to dismiss criminal charges against two antiabortion activists who secretly entered abortion providers’ meetings, recorded conversations and posted them online. https://t.co/pMiX7ex8kp

name: sfchronicle
text: Looks like it’s safe to talk basketball. Whether it’s a week, a month or the entire restarted #NBA season, let’s enjoy a major American sport while we can, writes columnist @Bruce_Jenkins1: https://t.co/HOeAzCnXk0
